item.title: WAN Network Connections From Copper to Fiber
item.description:
By: John Shepler As the demand for more bandwidth increases, so do LAN, MAN, and WAN speeds. This puts pressure on both copper and fiber-based telecommunication networks to upgrade their speeds more frequently. Let’s examine the options for both traditional TDM (Time Division Multiplexing) and IP (Internet Protocol) networks. Traditional Copper Telecom Lines Copper wiring has been the foundation of electronic communication since the telegraph and telephone networks. While the telegraph is obsolete, the telephone is transitioning technologically, with voice becoming a converged network service...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/wan-network-connections-from-copper-to-fiber/

item.title: Backing Up Broadband
item.description:
Over the past few decades, broadband internet has become essential for businesses, with speeds and data usage skyrocketing. This begs the question: what happens if your internet goes down? We’ve Quietly Become Dependent The shift to digital operations has been so gradual that many businesses don’t realize the impact of a complete internet outage. You understand the consequences of a power outage, but have you considered how to maintain operations if your internet connection fails?..
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/backing-up-broadband/

item.title: Gigabit Ethernet Replaces DS3 and T3
item.description:
By: John Shepler T3 lines and DS3 bandwidth, once a cornerstone of telecom services, are becoming outdated with the emergence of newer technologies like Carrier Ethernet WAN, point-to-point microwave for business, and DOCSIS 3 cable broadband. Let’s explore the options available for your business in the 50 to 1000 Mbps speed range. Transitioning from Traditional Telco T1 Lines Bell Labs revolutionized long-distance digital transmission after World War II with their T-Carrier system, introducing T1 and T3 services...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/gigabit-ethernet-replaces-ds3-and-t3/

item.title: Your 50 Mbps WAN Bandwidth Options
item.description:
By: John Shepler The need for 50 Mbps bandwidth has increased due to businesses needing to use cloud services, access remote data centers, transfer large data files, run e-commerce platforms, send high-resolution images, and distribute video content. There are various ways to get 50 Mbps bandwidth connectivity, each with its own benefits and drawbacks. DS3 & T3 DS3, or T3, is a traditional telecom service designed for transmitting many calls simultaneously between switching centers...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/your-50-mbps-wan-bandwidth-options/
